data.text: Surly Disc Trucker or Bridge Club for Bikepacking?

I am trying to decide between 2 Surly bikes for bikepacking. We will probably see more on-road vs. off-road riding. But want to be prepared overall. I am looking at the Disc Trucker and Bridge Club. Any pluses and minus would be helpful. Thank you in advance. My first bikepacking trip was on my 2004 Cannondale R2000 triple. Mainly roads and credit card. Short off road through a vineyard and the dirt gave way and hit my head on the ground. 25cm is not that wide.
I have a straggler and I love it. You can’t go wrong with surly. The trucker and BC are both great bikes that will do the job.
data.author: Aj Sake

data.text: Unrelated, I have a Karate Monkey and it's good for camping. My understanding is that the trucker is for hauling your entire belongings across the world. I used to ride the Salsa Marrakesh, which is a similar bike. I found it to be more than I needed almost all of the time, but it was great for carrying loads. The bridge club is more of an all-arounder for the rest of us. I've heard great things about all Surly bikes, and I love mine. If it were for me, and I was mainly going to go camping, I'd lean toward the bridge club.
data.author: Lance Lennick

data.text: We are working up to a cross country run in 2023 or 2024. We are now doing week-long +/- 600 milers (6-7 days). How does that affect your thoughts?
data.author: Dan Hurley

data.text: I'd say ride them both and see which you prefer. I'm sure you'll be happy either way. maybe go with your favorite color?
data.author: Lance Lennick

data.text: most surly owners I know (myself included) swear by them. A lot of people start off with the trucker or the cross check (although the straggler is a little more aggressive than the cross check). You can’t go wrong.
data.author: Aj Sake

data.text: I have a trucker and it is a nice ride. Solid and comfy.
data.author: Tom Kucklick

data.text: Disc trucker is ok for pavement and gravel. If it gets much rougher you’ll need the bridge club with the 27.5 wheel size (2.4”) The 700c trucker has the same size tires as the 700c bridge club (41c). You said bikepacking so no panniers?
data.author: Ron Hall

data.text: probably pannierss
data.author: Dan Hurley

data.text: I have a disc trucker and it’s been great - pannier front and back and handles shingle roads etc (even with the corrugations and no suspension). Haven’t tried the other but can’t go wrong with a Surly!
data.author: Wayne Whiting

data.text: I'd go bridge club, super under-rated bike, and can't beat the price. tho, honestly, the Ogre had always been one of my favorite bikes. If I could make a drop bar ogre fit me, with a 2x drivetrain, that'd be my ideal bike.
data.author: Kaelin Fox

data.text: Bridge club. Has wider tires for off road. You want a bike that will handle the worst surface you will encounter. I have a km with 3” and a Jones lwb with 2.6. I ride them both on the road when im not bikepacking.
data.author: Bruce Peterson

data.text: Get on both at bike shop and do little riding.. you'll know witch one you should get.. feels right!
data.author: Shawn Bowman

data.text: BTW if you want a custom build on Disc Trucker consider talking to me.
data.author: Tony Mitchelhill

data.text: Looking at both models, I think you’ll be happy either way. Surly makes quality bicycles. My preference, I would go with the disc trucker because of the geometry and more hand positions on those handlebars. Looks like the disc specifies a stronger wheel(36H spoke) and hub (12x100), but the bridge has higher gearing with a 51t cog vs DT’s 48t large cog. Same size tire width and diameter except tread on the bridge club. Drivetrain looks slightly better on bridge club but I think disc trucker is more versatile and true to what you picture when you think touring. Long haul trucker was a fantastic model. In the end it’s your choice and preference. People tour on all sorts of bicycles, whether it’s a hybrid, hardtail, road, touring, etc and all seem to enjoy the ride.
data.author: Alex Olivares

data.text: My first small tour was on a modified giant cypress st hybrid bicycle with 700x28c tires.
data.author: Alex Olivares

data.text: The Trucker rides better loaded than unloaded, which is a great thing if that’s it’s sole purpose. The Bridge club is a lot snappier unloaded but is fine loaded too, just not a plush and stable as the LHT.
data.author: Kathy Knapp
